WHAT DID WESTERN CANADIAN FAMILIES EAT?

A QUESTIONNAIRE

(Instructions: Fill in as much of this questionnaire as you can and mail it to Saskatchewan Archives Office, Box 100, University of Saskatchewan, Saskatoon, Sask.)

Name: Miss. Wanda Eaton
Address: West Mountain, Sask.
Birthplace: West Mountain

1. INTRODUCTORY QUESTIONS
What year did you start housekeeping in Eastern Canada? 1942
Where did you set up housekeeping? West Mountain
Where had you been living before that? Regina, Saskatchewan
For how many people did you prepare meals? 5
How far was it to your nearest store? 3 miles
How often could a visit be made to the store? Occasionally
What groceries did you usually buy in those earliest years?
flour, sugar, tea, coffee, oatmeal, baking powder, salt, syrup

2. FLOUR AND OTHER GRAIN PRODUCTS
What brand of white flour did you use in the early years? American Flour
In what quantities did you buy it? One hundred pounds at a time
What was the usual price per hundred pounds of white flour? $2.50
How much did you use graham flour? None
Whole wheat flour? None
Was flour milled locally? No
How far away? What year? 1943
What was the price for a twenty pound bag of rolled oats? 75¢
What other grain products did you use?
Cornmeal? Yes
Whole wheat? No
Farina? Yes
Other? None
Did you grind your own wheat for porridge? No
How did you grind it? In a grinder closer than Regina

22. Please add other details from your early experiences of buying groceries and securing foods in other ways during pioneer days in Western Canada. Include items not mentioned above, quality, methods of merchandising, prices, problems of storage, shortages and other details. [Use back of page if more space is needed].

Cream was always churned and packed in 20, 30, 40 or 50 pound tubs to be sold. The buttermilk was made into Buttermilk soup, a very tasty dish when properly made.

Flour porridge or Minute Porridge was served for breakfast. It was made of flour, boiled milk and raisins, and served with cream and sugar.

Today you can go into town at any time of the year and purchase fresh vegetables.

Bread was always chewed and packed in 20, 30, 40 or 50 pound tins to be sold. The buttermilk was made into buttermilk soup, a very tasty dish when properly made.

Flour porridge or Minute Pudding was served for breakfast. It was made of flour, boiled milk and raisins, and served with cream and sugar.

Today you can go into town at any time of the year and purchase fresh vegetables.
